sentence_samples.sentence: Should it be possible for me to override the interface User {} in that passport type definition by using a similar process then?

sentence_samples.speaker: AnyhowStep
sentence_samples.sentence: [<-URL->] Yeah, you can use declaration merging for most stuff. [<-CODE->] Try sticking that in some file and checking if it shows up in Request.user. Although the singleton type True may seem artificial, ... @AnyhowStep Stares at TypeScript and its literal types

sentence_samples.speaker: nspaeth
sentence_samples.sentence: That does seem to work. I was testing it on express.user instead of express.req.user or Request.user. What is causing it to merge with Request instead of being added to express? (Notice how User is a sibling of Request, not a child in the passport typedef)

sentence_samples.speaker: AnyhowStep
sentence_samples.sentence: You're saying req.user does not contain myCustomLabel?

sentence_samples.speaker: nspaeth
sentence_samples.sentence: No, I am saying it does, but that was unexpected for me. I was expecting to be able to do: [<-CODE->] Because User and Request are declared at the same level. I'm just trying to understand how User isn't merged into the rootexpress namespace, but Request is.

sentence_samples.speaker: AnyhowStep
sentence_samples.sentence: Where is this user variable coming from, in your first example? I've never known user to be a property of import * as express from "express"; Then again, it's not like I use express often

sentence_samples.speaker: nspaeth
sentence_samples.sentence: [<-CODE->]

sentence_samples.speaker: AnyhowStep
sentence_samples.sentence: Just use req.user.myCustomField or use Express.User, instead of trying to import {User}

sentence_samples.speaker: nspaeth
sentence_samples.sentence: I understand, but myCustomField isn't part of the express package either. So I was just trying to understand why User didn't get merged into express the same way myCustonField got merged into Request.user. For sure though, [<-CODE->] solves my problem, and I'll be using that.

sentence_samples.speaker: AnyhowStep
sentence_samples.sentence: Because User is not part of the express package. Request is part of the express package, though. express.Request extends express-static-core.Request extends global.Express.Request. So, when you import {Request} from "express", you're importing express.Express. It just so happens that it extends global.Express.Request. But there is no express.User. So, you can't import {User} from "express"

sentence_samples.speaker: nspaeth
sentence_samples.sentence: Ah, I see, thanks.

sentence_samples.speaker: ghost~57cbaf6040f3a6eec0634f49
sentence_samples.sentence: What is the use of docker?

sentence_samples.speaker: ghost~57cbaf6040f3a6eec0634f49
sentence_samples.sentence: Can anyone explain about it in a very simple lang?

sentence_samples.speaker: SISheogorath
sentence_samples.sentence: dpnashsh: Docker is an container engine (means it isolates applications) and orchestration system (means it places applications on various hosts and makes sure there is a fail over when a host dies). It provides all tooling to create such containers. Means you can download images of applications and/or build them yourself in a reproducable way using Dockerfiles.
